page.title: 02Landscape
page.content: The area is an undulating panorama of arable and pasture land bisected by hedgerows, presenting an ever-varying landscape through the seasons. The old pasture still reveals the ridge and furrow from medieval times. The ground rises steeply from the River Welland valley in the south to Nevill Holt in the north and Bringhurst in the west. The trees are a mixture of horsechestnut, oak, lime, ash, fir and beech with a greater concentration around the villages except for the odd spinney and Holt Wood. The avenue of horsechestnuts leading up to Nevill Holt is particularly striking. The houses, concentrated in the villages, are a pleasant mixture of natural stone and old red brick, roofed with slates with the occasional thatched roof and colour washed wall. Most modern houses are suitably blended.
